content:
I've reformatted the statement and edited the wording slightly.

I've corrected the wrongly spelled variable name in Constraints section.

I've added "Test 1" as the name of the first test since the name was missing before. I've also renumbered all the validators from the second one onwards because the name "Validator 2" was missing before.
Added "write answer" to stub generator.
I downgraded the puzzle to Easy.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: fun

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's fun

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really enjoyed that puzzle as it was pretty straightforward, but required multiple steps to decrypt the string. The 12 base idea was also an interesting one as I had to stop for a moment with "nov" and "dec" cases.

These 4 lines are a bit confusing

may -> 4 becomes 4 in base 12 which is 4
jul -> 6 becomes 6 in base 12 which is 6
so mayjul is 46
46 is in base 12 so 46 also becomes 54 in decimal

It is explicitly stated that both 4 and 6 are base 12, even though then they are concatenated as string literals, and form a base 12 number.
In case of novdec, would this mean

nov -> 10 becomes 10 in base 12 which is 12 //this is the interesting part
jan -> 1 becomes 1 in base 12 which is 1
so mayjul is 101

If this is the case, then I'd include either nov or dec in the example, and if it is not the case, then I'd just omit the "becomes X in base 12 which is X" part. "may -> 4" and "jul -> 6" in itself is actually more clear with the followup text

In the explanation, I'd use a word that does not represent a number character, because at the moment it is a bit confusing that at first 'mayjul represents "6"', then 'so mayjul is 46', and finally back to 'so mayjul ->6'

Maybe you could use sepsep, and at first say 'sepseprepresents the charater "h"', then start the followup by starting with "In order to find that out..." and finish up similarly, but don't omit the "s

Nice puzzle :)
I don't have anything to add to the concept itself.
While I myself don't care about it that much, you should fix the spelling, and make the explanation a bit more clear

I'd start by capitalizing the first letters of the sentences.
Other than that, a few errors I noticed (likely not all, because I'm also not that good with grammar)
- detective geek have a... -> Detective geek has a...
- super power -> superpower
- everytime -> every time
- he start writing on paper -> he starts writing on paper
- skip this steps -> skip these steps
- going to happend around : 15:30 -> going to happen around : 15:30
- can be splitted into -> can be split into
- There should be no spaces before colons

Creating sections using some empty lines might also help the reader.

Quick solution in ruby:
t,*a=`tr "#*" 10`.split
puts ("%04d"%t.to_i(2)).sub(/../){$&+?:}
$><<a.map{|s|s.gsub(/.../){[*?0..?9,?A,?B][%w(jan feb mar apr may jun jul aug sep oct nov dec).index _1]}.to_i(12).chr}*""


I think there is a problem with validator 2 since it is the only test case that uses characters out the normal 128 ascii characters. It uses 'é' which is part of the extended 256 ascii and would not be converted using ruby's .chr, and the person would even get 100% using the test cases only to fail the validators. So i suggest you replace that character. Note how in my code i had to add chr("UTF-8") instead

Nice problem! Passed all test cases without issues.
I think it would be better at easy difficulty, since it takes time to implement but its really very straightforward

I like the concept of this puzzle, but I believe there is an error in validator 2: the 'é' is written as 'febaugjun', which I believe is invalid (in fact, I don't think that 'é' can be written anyway, as 'decdec' I believe translates to 169, and 'é' is 233). 

Also, it was unclear to me how the conversion of the months worked; I would write as the table:
"jan": 0
"feb": 1
"mar": 2 (I believe that the 3 was a typo)
...
"oct": 9
"nov": A (10 written in base 12)
"dec": B (11 written in base 12)

I would also include the 2 last notes for more clarity, as well as make a second example like you did with 'mayjul' for something like 'octnov' to show how 'nov' and 'dec' would be translated.

Other than those notes, however, this is a great puzzle! This may also just be a problem of me not understanding it; I'm not sure if other people would have trouble understanding the conversions.
Actually, I just realized that I made the mistake in the base-12 conversion, and that 'febaugjun' is actually 1*144 + 7*12 + 5*1, which adds to 233. Nevermind about that one!
i fixed the second validator
yeah i think i got waht u mean i will edit it
whats that ? wat u mean
You may check it in the bottom left hand corner here.
oh yeah thanks i must have forgotten abt that
You're welcome!
thank you

Alright that's good i've changed the code to remove the utf-8.
And btw i just noticed that all the addresses are supposed to be in algeria lmao
nope there is also india , korea usa uk. his power work all around the globe
